div.p: Barriers to accessibility are obstacles that make things more difficult,
and sometimes impossible, for those of us with disabilities.
Barriers exclude people.
But when we understand and remove these barriers,
we create an accessible federal public service that is inclusive for everyone.
Let's look at an example:
Julio has been working in the federal public service for around eight years.
His left leg was recently amputated and he now uses a wheelchair to get around.
There are two stairs that lead to his office,
which create a barrier and prevent him from going to work.
As a solution, his employer installed a ramp.
Julio can now get to his office -- just like he used to.
But let's think about this for a minute.
If the office had been built with inclusive design,
the ramp would have already been there.
This means Julio would never have been excluded in the first place.
It's important to consider physical barriers
to accessibility that might be overlooked.
Similar to a ramp, automatic doors allow those of us using wheelchairs
or mobility devices to get in and out of the workspace.
They also help people with strollers or bicycles,
and others who might be carrying large bags and boxes.
Let's make workspaces accessible right from the start.
Using inclusive design creates a better experience for everyone!
Accessibility is a big step towards inclusion.
And it starts by taking action.
Together, let's build an inclusive
and accessibility-confident federal public service.
